p: In addition, various studies have reported a direct relationship between the spread and contagion capacity of some viruses with the atmospheric levels and mobility of air pollutants ( Ciencewicki and Jaspers, 2007; Sedlmaier et al., 2009). The avian influenza virus (H5N1) could be transported across long distances by fine dust during Asian storms ( Chen et al., 2010), and atmospheric levels of PM 2.5, PM 10, carbon monoxide, NO 2 and sulphur dioxide were shown to influence the diffusion of the human respiratory syncytial virus in children ( Ye et al., 2016), and the daily spread of the measles virus in China ( Chen et al., 2017; Peng et al., 2020).
